data.text:
Let’s make one thing clear right off the bat: this article is a work in progress. It will be updated regularly and it’s worth checking in on from time to time.

For every year, I’ve listed a number of films I’ve seen in the past and need to rewatch. And I’ve mentioned, in most categories, the films I have yet to see. I’ve seen a lot of films over the years, some of them too long ago to properly rate by my current metrics, and some of them I simply didn’t rate at the time because I wasn’t paying quite enough attention to them, or what have you. Add in the films I’ve just plain never seen, and you’ve got a lot of room for improvement.

But even allowing for that, I’ve done my very best with those films I’ve seen, and I’ve seen some damned good ones in this decade – and more than a few of them are severely underrated and well worth looking into.

It works out like this: if I have at least five films for a given year which I rate a 77 or higher (***½ or ****), I can put together a Best Picture category, and a full set of nominees from all the films I’ve seen for that year. And if I have ten or more films which I rate highly enough, I do a full 10 nominees for Best Picture, which I generally prefer to do. At the moment, I can only do so for a few years this decade, but I hope to do so with all of them in due course of time.

And in case you’re wondering why the 60s are the first decade I did a full post for, well, I’ve got enough films I rate highly enough to qualify for every year in the decade. I’m pretty sure no earlier decade can say that, at least at the moment.

One last note: it can be tricky to know what year to put a given film in, especially for foreign films, which would sometimes take years to play in the States. If a film was nominated for an Oscar in a given year, or submitted to the Oscars but not nominated in a given year, I’ll put it in that year. Otherwise, I typically go with the year it was initially released.

One asterisk (*) means an Oscar nominee, two asterisks (**) means an Oscar winner.

1960:

Picture:

Psycho

Elmer Gantry*

Tunes of Glory

Hiroshima mon amour

Wild River

I’ve seen four of the Best Picture nominees, two of which will appear on these lists – Gantry and The Sundowners (my #7) – and two which I need to rewatch – The Apartment (which won) and The Alamo (which isn’t all that great); the fifth nominee, Sons and Lovers, is rather hard to find. Other major films from this year which I’ve seen but need to rewatch include Can-Can, Exodus, Inherit the Wind, The Magnificent Seven, Ocean’s 11, and Sergeant Rutledge.

Director:

Alfred Hitchcock, Psycho*

Alain Resnais, Hiroshima mon amour

Richard Brooks, Elmer Gantry

Elia Kazan, Wild River

Ronald Neame, Tunes of Glory

After rewatching Psycho, Hitchcock ekes out the win for his iconic horror film, with Resnais’ nouvelle vague innovations a close second. Kudos to the directors for noticing Hitchcock here even if the Academy didn’t fully appreciate Psycho elsewhere. The Oscar winner was Billy Wilder; Fred Zinnemann was nominated for The Sundowners and just misses the top 5.

Actor:

Burt Lancaster, Elmer Gantry**

Anthony Perkins, Psycho

Alec Guinness, Tunes of Glory

Robert Mitchum, The Sundowners

Eiji Okada, Hiroshima mon amour

It’s hard to decide between Lancaster’s Oscar-winning turn and Perkins’ infamously snubbed performance; I’m honestly tempted to push Perkins Supporting (where he’d easily win), but for now he’s here, and a close second. Also snubbed was Mitchum, who was also snubbed for Home from the Hill (he won the NBR for both, however). But the Academy only nominated him once, for his breakthrough role in Story of G.I. Joe.

Actress:

Emmanuelle Riva, Hiroshima mon amour

Deborah Kerr, The Sundowners*

Lee Remick, Wild River

Jean Simmons, Elmer Gantry

Nancy Kwan, The World of Suzie Wong

Riva would finally get an Oscar nomination 52 years later, for Amour. Kerr was nominated six times, but never won; the Oscar went to Elizabeth Taylor for BUtterfield 8, generally considered a terrible choice, especially over Shirley MacLaine in The Apartment. The only other nominee I’ve seen is Greer Garson as Eleanor Roosevelt in Sunrise at Campobello, but I didn’t think she was really that strong.

Supporting Actor:

John Mills, Tunes of Glory

Laurence Olivier, Spartacus

George Peppard, Home from the Hill

Arthur Kennedy, Elmer Gantry

George Hamilton, Home from the Hill

The Oscar went to Peter Ustinov in Spartacus, who may well bump Hamilton whenever I go back to that film; I’ve only seen it once and wasn’t that impressed by it (it’s my #8 right now, a low ***½), but I really ought to give it another chance. Peppard won the NBR; it’s really odd, given that it was a fairly prestigious film by an Oscar-winning director, that Home got no Oscar nominations. I also considered nudging Martin Balsam onto this list for Psycho.

The other Oscar nominees that I’ve seen are Jack Kruschen in The Apartment (a bit strange that they chose him over Fred MacMurray), Sal Mineo in Exodus, and Chill Wills in The Alamo, who ran one of the most infamous campaign ads in Oscar history.

Supporting Actress:

Shirley Jones, Elmer Gantry**

Janet Leigh, Psycho*

Glynis Johns, The Sundowners*

Jo Van Fleet, Wild River

Ann Shoemaker, Sunrise at Campobello

Jones, playing against type as the prostitute who’d been corrupted by Elmer Gantry, wins with me and the Academy. Leigh is a pretty close second, but it drops off after that; I don’t remember if Eleanor Parker in Home from the Hill would be lead or supporting. There’s also Kay Walsh and Susannah York in Tunes of Glory to consider; I’ll need to rewatch the film to see where I put them.

Ensemble:

Elmer Gantry

Tunes of Glory

The Sundowners

Home from the Hill

Wild River

An easy choice here, with all the great performances in Gantry; there’s also Edward Andrews and Dean Jagger, who would probably be honorable mentions in Supporting Actor.

Original Screenplay:

Hiroshima mon amour*

Jigoku

That’s all I’ve got for now, and Jigoku barely rates mention alongside Marguerite Duras’ amazing script for Hiroshima. The Oscar went to The Apartment (deservedly), which was the only Picture winner this decade to win Original Screenplay; in this decade only seven nominees in this category will even get Picture nominations, the absurdity of which will become very clear as we go along.

Adapted Screenplay:

Elmer Gantry**

Tunes of Glory*

Psycho

Home from the Hill

The Sundowners*

Another instance where I agree with the Academy, at least for now; they do pretty well in his category, and they also nominated Inherit the Wind, which would easily have been my #3.

Cinematography:

Hiroshima mon amour

Psycho*

Wild River

Elmer Gantry

Jigoku

The Oscars went to Spartacus and Sons and Lovers; I don’t remember being hugely impressed by the work in Spartacus, but that’s part of why I need to rewatch it (I’m pretty sure the print I saw was of the infamous 2010 restoration). I am surprised that they Academy passed over two Picture nominees in favor of BUtterfield 8 and Pepe.

Editing:

Hiroshima mon amour

Psycho*

Tunes of Glory

Elmer Gantry

Wild River

Home from the Hill

The Oscar went to The Apartment and the nominees included The Alamo, Inherit the Wind, and Spartacus, which might at least be worth a spot on this list. But for now, I’m much more impressed by the fascinating editing in Hiroshima, though the shower scene alone puts Psycho a close second.

Production Design:

Spartacus**

Jigoku

Psycho*

Elmer Gantry

Wild River

I will say, the sets in Spartacus are fantastic. The black-and-white Oscar went to The Apartment; Sunrise at Campobello was nominated for the color Oscar, not a bad choice but not interesting enough to get on here. Jigoku was never getting nominated, but the sets in the final sequence (set in Hell) are awesomely grotesque.

Costume Design:

Spartacus**

Elmer Gantry

Wild River

Sunrise at Campobello*

Jigoku

Again, Spartacus deserved this Oscar. And Campobello makes my top 5 here.

Makeup:

Jigoku

Spartacus

Hiroshima mon amour

Just look at this.

Score:

Psycho

Spartacus*

Hiroshima mon amour

Elmer Gantry*

Wild River

There’s no question for me that Psycho wins this; the shower scene is one of the most iconic pieces of film music ever written, but it’s a brilliant score all the way through. I’ve actually seen all the five of the Oscar nominees; the others are The Alamo (a solid score), the winner, Exodus (a good main theme, at least), and The Magnificent Seven (an iconic score). Alex North, who did the music for Spartacus, never did win the Oscar despite a whopping 15 nominations.

Song:

n/a

There’s just nothing in the films I’ve seen to qualify. The Oscar went to the title song from Never on Sunday (which is at least a good song) and “The Green Leaves of Summer” from The Alamo, so well-used at the beginning of Inglourious Basterds, was nominated (and would probably be my winner).

Sound Mixing:

Psycho

Spartacus

Wild River

Jigoku

Hiroshima mon amour

The Oscar went to The Alamo (as I recall, a decent choice); bizarrely, they passed over Spartacus, with its fight scenes and battles, for Sunrise at Campobello, whose sound design is hardly worth mentioning.

Sound Effects:

Psycho

Spartacus

Jigoku

The Bellboy

The Sundowners

Visual Effects:

Jigoku

The Oscar went to The Time Machine, which I haven’t seen. But the Hell scenes in Jigoku have some very enjoyable effects work.

1961:

Picture:

Yojimbo

Splendor in the Grass

Blast of Silence

The Misfits

One Hundred and One Dalmatians

Another year with a lot of big films I haven’t seen in years, including four of the five Oscar nominees (winner West Side Story, The Guns of Navarone, The Hustler, and Judgment at Nuremberg) as well as films like Breakfast at Tiffany’s, El Cid, King of Kings, One Two Three, and Pocketful of Miracles.

Director:

Akira Kurosawa, Yojimbo

Elia Kazan, Splendor in the Grass

Allen Baron, Blast of Silence

John Huston, The Misfits

Marlon Brando, One-Eyed Jacks

For now, Brando gets a nod for his only turn behind the camera – and Baron gets in for by far his most notable effort (he mostly worked in television). As in 1960, a foreign-language director beats four English-language efforts, but what Kurosawa does in Yojimbo is just breath-taking. The Oscar went to Robert Wise and Jerome Robbins for West Side Story – a very good choice as I recall, but I’ll probably stick with Kurosawa.

Actor:

Toshiro Mifune, Yojimbo

Clark Gable, The Misfits

Warren Beatty, Splendor in the Grass

Vittorio De Sica, General della Rovere

Marlon Brando, One-Eyed Jacks

De Sica and Brando won’t last long once I properly make room for Paul Newman (The Hustler) and Maximilian Schell (Oscar winner for Judgment). But the top three are very strong indeed, including Gable in his poignant final role.

Actress:

Natalie Wood, Splendor in the Grass*

Marilyn Monroe, The Misfits

Just two nominees for now; the Oscar winner was Sophia Loren for Two Women, which I haven’t seen, nor have I seen Audrey Hepburn’s nominated performance in Breakfast at Tiffany’s (which, to be fair, I’m not that anxious to see). But I have seen Piper Laurie’s nominated turn in The Hustler, which will give Wood’s great performance a run for its money.

Supporting Actor:

Pat Hingle, Splendor in the Grass

Eli Wallach, The Misfits

Tatsuya Nakadai, Yojimbo

Karl Malden, One-Eyed Jacks

Lionel Stander, Blast of Silence

Hingle wins this pretty easily as Warren Beatty’s father; Montgomery Clift’s heartbreaking performance in Judgment will, at the very least, bump him to #2, to say nothing of George Chakiris’ Oscar-winning turn Bernardo in West Side Story and the great nominated performances by Jackie Gleason and George C. Scott in The Hustler.

Special mention to Stander, who narrates Blast; it’s some of my favorite narration in film history.

Supporting Actress:

Barbara Loden, Splendor in the Grass

Pina Pellicer, One-Eyed Jacks

Isuzu Yamada, Yojimbo

Betty Lou Gerson, One Hundred and One Dalmatians

Thelma Ritter, The Misfits

Again, this line-up will change once I properly slot Rita Moreno (Oscar winner) and Judy Garland (Oscar nominee) in here. But Loden, who was in very few films (and directed just one, the little-seen but critically acclaimed Wanda) is fantastic as Warren Beatty’s free-spirited sister.

Ensemble:

Splendor in the Grass

Yojimbo

The Misfits

One-Eyed Jacks

For now, the great work in Splendor wins. For now.

Original Screenplay:

Yojimbo

Blast of Silence

Splendor in the Grass**

Only three films for now, but they’re all great. One could argue Yojimbo is adapted from Red Harvest, but neither Wikipedia nor the IMDb list it as a source.

Splendor won the Oscar, of course; it’s the only Oscar I’ve ever held, as screenwriter William Inge was an alum of my alma mater.

Adapted Screenplay:

The Misfits

One-Eyed Jacks

One Hundred and One Dalmatians

General della Rovere(*)

The Oscar went to Judgment at Nuremberg (a good choice) and the nominees included The Hustler and West Side Story. General della Rovere barely gets on – it’s not a great script, despite interesting elements – and while it was nominated for an Oscar, it was nominated as an original script, despite being adapted from either a short story or a novel (sources differ).

Cinematography:

Yojimbo

Blast of Silence

One-Eyed Jacks*

The Misfits

The Sand Castle

One of the ironies of Jacks‘ long stint in public-domain hell is that the Oscar-nominated cinematography has been so hard to appreciate. The Criterion Collection fixed that. The Sand Castle is far from a great film (or even a very good one) but it has some neat imagery. The Oscar winners were West Side Story (very good) and The Hustler (solid).

Editing:

Yojimbo

Blast of Silence

Splendor in the Grass

The Misfits

Another case where West Side Story won the Oscar, and rightly so; “Tonight” is one of the best-edited scenes I’ve ever seen. But there’s some fantastic work in Yojimbo and Blast.

Production Design:

Yojimbo

Splendor in the Grass

General della Rovere

One-Eyed Jacks

Blast of Silence

As with Editing, the Oscars went to West Side Story and The Hustler – two contemporary films. Yojimbo wasn’t nominated but The Absent-Minded Professor was.

Costume Design:

Yojimbo*

Splendor in the Grass

Babes in Toyland*

One-Eyed Jacks

General della Rovere

At least Yojimbo was nominated, even if it lost the Oscar to La Dolce Vita (which I haven’t seen). The other Oscar went to West Side Story, a rare win for a contemporary film in Color Costume Design.

Makeup:

Yojimbo

Babes in Toyland

One-Eyed Jacks

Yes, Babes in Toyland is a stupid film, but Disney put a lot of money into it and, in some respects, it shows.

Score:

Blast of Silence

Yojimbo

One Hundred and One Dalmatians

The Misfits

General della Rovere

Blast has an awesome score by jazz musician Meyer Kupferman. The Oscar went to Henry Mancini for Breakfast at Tiffany’s, while the nominees include the great score from El Cid (and Fanny, which shouldn’t have qualified since the score itself was written for the stage musical – the film used the music but not the lyrics).

In 6th place is The Sand Castle, which is by no means a great film, but has a rather good score.

Song:

“Cruella De Vil,” One Hundred and One Dalmatians

“Dressed in Black,” Blast of Silence

“Tivoli Night,” Reptilicus

“Dressed in Black” is a legitimately good song. “Tivoli Night”…it’s better than nothing. “Moon River” won the Oscar and should win this easily whenever I finally see Tiffany’s.

Sound Mixing:

Yojimbo

The Misfits

Blast of Silence

One-Eyed Jacks

General della Rovere

Another worthy win for West Side Story, although the top three are pretty strong in their own right,

Sound Effects:

Yojimbo

Reptilicus

General della Rovere

One Hundred and One Dalmatians

Blast of Silence

The sound effects are by far the best thing about Reptilicus.

Visual Effects:

Babes in Toyland

That’s all I’ve got for now; the Oscar went to The Guns of Navarone, which is probably better.

1962:

Picture:

Lawrence of Arabia**

The Manchurian Candidate

The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance

Last Year at Marienbad

Jules and Jim

Ride the High Country

The Trial

Cleo from 5 to 7

Lonely Are the Brave

Divorce Italian Style

Not only do I have a full 10 Picture nominees just from what I’ve ranked, but I’m working with an all-time great top 5: Lawrence is my pick for the greatest film of all time, Candidate is in my top 20, Liberty Valance might be my favorite Western ever made, Marienbad is one of the most fascinating enigmas I’ve ever seen, and Jules and Jim (which I saw only recently) is deservedly iconic. The rest of my top 10 are a bit heavy on films I need to rewatch.

I’ve seen all five Best Picture nominees; Lawrence won, and is the best choice the Academy ever made, of course, but aside from The Longest Day (my current #12, a high ***), I haven’t seen the others in ages. They are The Music Man, Mutiny on the Bounty, and To Kill a Mockingbird. There are also a lot of major films I still need to see, but these lists can only get stronger; 1962 was really one of the great years in film history.

Director:

David Lean, Lawrence of Arabia**

John Frankenheimer, The Manchurian Candidate

Alain Resnais, Last Year at Marienbad

François Truffaut, Jules and Jim

John Ford, The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance

Lean wins the Oscar, naturally, and wins with me fairly easily, though Frankenheimer and Resnais would strongly contend in most other years. I’ve actually seen two of the other Oscar nominees recently enough; Arthur Penn for The Miracle Worker and Frank Perry for David and Lisa. Neither really merited the nod, but at least Penn would earn his next nomination, in 1967; Perry, from what I’ve seen, never quite got there.

The other Oscar nominees were Pietro Germi for Divorce Italian Style – a good job of direction but outmatched in this year – and Robert Mulligan for Mockingbird.

Actor:

Peter O’Toole, Lawrence of Arabia*

Frank Sinatra, The Manchurian Candidate

Laurence Harvey, The Manchurian Candidate

Anthony Perkins, The Trial

James Stewart, The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance

O’Toole is easily my choice as well; he gives one of the greatest performances in film history. There’s a lot of competition for the remaining slots; in additional to the four above, there’s John Wayne in Liberty Valance, Joel McCrea and Randolph Scott in Ride the High Country, Kirk Douglas in Lonely Are the Brave, and Oskar Werner in Jules and Jim. And from the films I need to rewatch, there’s Oscar winner Gregory Peck in Mockingbird, Robert Preston in The Music Man, and whichever members of the Advise & Consent ensemble could be considered leads.

And that’s before mentioning the other three Oscar nominees: Jack Lemmon in Days of Wine and Roses, Burt Lancaster in Birdman of Alcatraz, and Marcello Mastroianni in Divorce Italian Style (enjoyable but can’t crack this top 5). Just a jam-packed year.

Actress:

Anne Bancroft, The Miracle Worker**

Corinne Marchand, Cleo from 5 to 7

Jeanne Moreau, Jules and Jim

Janet Margolin, David and Lisa

Delphine Seyrig, Last Year at Marienbad

A much weaker list than Actor; Bancroft is actually the only Oscar nominee I’ve seen, but she is very good indeed. She wins fairly handily; Marchand is quite good, but Moreau and Seyrig are in films more focused on the direction and writing than the acting (their roles are more enigmatic than three-dimensional), solid as they are. And Margolin is by far the best part of her film.

The other Oscar nominees were Bette Davis in What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?, Katherine Hepburn in Long Day’s Journey into Night, Geraldine Page in Sweet Bird of Youth, and Lee Remick in Days of Wine and Roses – none of which I’ve seen.

Supporting Actor:

Omar Sharif, Lawrence of Arabia*

Jack Hawkins, Lawrence of Arabia

Claude Rains, Lawrence of Arabia

Lee Marvin, The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance

Anthony Quinn, Lawrence of Arabia

If you think this category favors Lawrence now, just remember that there’s also Anthony Quayle, José Ferrer, Arthur Kennedy, and Alec Guinness to be considered. And then you have to consider Edmond O’Brien and Andy Devine in Liberty Valance, James Gregory in The Manchurian Candidate, Walter Matthau in Lonely Are he Brave, and Orson Welles in The Trial.

And that’s before getting into the rest of the Oscar category: winner Ed Begley in Sweet Bird of Youth, Victor Buono in Baby Jane, and Terence Stamp in Billy Budd. And, you know, all the supporting players in Advise & Consent, Brock Peters in Mockingbird, Paul Ford and Buddy Hackett in The Music Man…

Supporting Actress:

Patty Duke, The Miracle Worker**

Angela Lansbury, The Manchurian Candidate*

Janet Leigh, The Manchurian Candidate

Vera Miles, The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance

Mariette Hartley, Ride the High Country

Another category where the Academy got it right; Candidate is by far the better film and Lansbury is excellent in it, but Duke’s performance as Helen Keller is just incredible. The other three nominees straddle the line between lead and supporting, but I didn’t have much else to work with. The other Oscar nominees were Mary Badham in Mockingbird (who’s really a lead), Shirley Knight in Sweet Bird, and Thelman Ritter in Birdman.

Ensemble:

Lawrence of Arabia

The Manchurian Candidate

The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance

Ride the High Country

The Trial

It feels a bit weird not to have The Longest Day, with one of the starriest casts in film history, on this list, but most of them are just there for their star power rather than their acting ability.

Original Screenplay:

Last Year at Marienbad*

Ride the High Country

Divorce Italian Style**

Cleo from 5 to 7

I’m not really surprised that Divorce beat Marienbad; it’s a far more accessible film and a very clever one. But for me, Marienbad wins by a long way. The other Oscar nominees were Freud, That Touch of Mink, and Through a Glass Darkly.

Adapted Screenplay:

Lawrence of Arabia*

The Manchurian Candidate

The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance

Jules and Jim

The Trial

This, on the other hand, is one of the tightest top twos I’ve ever had. Manchurian Candidate has one of my favorite scripts ever written, with some of the most brilliantly offbeat dialogue in film history, but Lawrence is so brilliant in how it combines epic sweep, political turmoil, and personal drama that I give it the edge for the time being.

The rest of the Oscar category is a mixed bag. The winner was To Kill a Mockingbird (good, I’m sure), and they nominated Lolita, which probably deserved it, but they also nominated The Miracle Worker (solid but not great) and David and Lisa (pretty thin).

Cinematography:

Lawrence of Arabia**

Last Year at Marienbad

The Trial

The Manchurian Candidate

Ride the High Country

Back to an easy choice, with possibly the best cinematography in film history. It won the color Oscar, while The Longest Day won the black-and-white Oscar; an alright choice, but not on the level of Marienbad or Candidate.

Editing:

Lawrence of Arabia**

The Manchurian Candidate*

Last Year at Marienbad

Jules and Jim

The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance

Another hard choice; the brainwashing demonstration in Candidate is a masterpiece of editing, but Lawrence‘s ability to hold our fascination for four hours is partly dependent on the genius of Anne V. Coates’ work (and, of course, there’s the cut from Lawrence blowing out the match to the sun rising over the desert). At least Candidate was nominated.

Production Design:

Last Year at Marienbad

The Trial

Lawrence of Arabia**

The Wonderful World of the Brothers Grimm*

Divorce Italian Style

Is it weird that I push Lawrence to #3? Maybe it deserves the win, but I just think of it as being so much more about the exteriors, about the glorious scenery, than about the actual sets. Marienbad, on the other hand, has magnificent design throughout, with all the ornate halls and bedrooms the characters inhabit. The black-and-white Oscar went to Mockingbird.

Originally, I had Liberty Valance as my #5, but for now I have Divorce in that spot; the crumbling mansion where most of the action takes place is really a superbly realized setting.

Costume Design:

Lawrence of Arabia

The Wonderful World of the Brothers Grimm**

Jules and Jim

Waltz of the Toreadors

The Miracle Worker*

I can’t argue too much with Brothers Grimm winning, as it has some excellent costumes. But to not even nominate Lawrence (and to nominate Bon Voyage! and My Geisha instead) is just ridiculous. Baby Jane won the black-and-white Oscar, while Liberty Valance was nominated (its only nomination).

Makeup:

Lawrence of Arabia

The Wonderful World of the Brothers Grimm

The Longest Day

The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance

War Hunt

The use of brownface on Anthony Quinn and Alec Guinness is regrettable, but the work on Peter O’Toole throughout really helps to reinforce the grueling journey Lawrence goes on.

Score:

Lawrence of Arabia**

Jules and Jim

Last Year at Marienbad

Cleo from 5 to 7

The Wonderful World of the Brothers Grimm*

It’s one of the greatest scores in film history (I think I had it at #2 behind Koyaanisqatsi), so of course it won with me and the Academy. I should note that the score for Mutiny on the Bounty, which was nominated, is really good – the best thing about the film – and will easily get a spot on this list when I rewatch it. I also considered squeezing Divorce Italian Style on here for its droll score, but decided not to.

Song:

“The Longest Day,” The Longest Day

“Le Tourbillon,” Jules and Jim

“Ah-Oom,” The Wonderful World of the Brothers Grimm

“The Longest Day” is a really good song and I’m kind of surprised it wasn’t nominated. “Le Tourbillon” is a delightful song and does seem to have been written for the film, so it was an easy pick. “Ah-Oom” is the most memorable song in Grimm; it’s here more because I don’t have more to work with. The Oscar went to the title song from Days of Wine and Roses; one of the nominees was “Follow Me” from Mutiny on the Bounty which would probably be #3 on this list.

Sound Mixing:

Lawrence of Arabia**

The Manchurian Candidate

The Longest Day

Last Year at Marienbad

Ride the High Country

An easy choice, what with all the battle and desert scenes. Very curious as to why Bon Voyage! and That Touch of Mink were nominated over The Longest Day.

Sound Effects:

Lawrence of Arabia

The Longest Day

The Wonderful World of the Brothers Grimm

The Manchurian Candidate

Ride the High Country

The Academy would finally institute this category the following year, but I’m sure Lawrence or Longest Day would’ve won.

Visual Effects:

The Wonderful World of the Brothers Grimm

The Longest Day**

Lawrence of Arabia

I actually don’t think the work in The Longest Day is that amazing (some is good, some is clunky), so I give Grimm the edge, with its Puppetoons, dragon, and so forth.

1963:

Picture:

8½

Revenge of a Kabuki Actor (also known as An Actor’s Revenge)

America, America*

The Haunting

The Birds

Back to guesswork, with a lot of films I haven’t seen in years, and even those which appear in these lists deserve another look. Tom Jones is a particular example; it won four Oscars including Best Picture and got five acting nominations. I wasn’t a big fan when I saw it, rating it a 74 (high ***), but that was over a decade ago, and I suspect I’d find more to appreciate nowadays. On the other hand, if I rate Tom lower than most, I rate Oscar nominee Cleopatra higher than most, at a 67 (low ***). The other Picture nominees are How the West Was Won (haven’t seen recently) and Lilies of the Field (haven’t seen).

Other major films I’ve seen and need to rewatch include The Cardinal, Ivan’s Childhood, The List of Adrian Messenger, The Nutty Professor, and The Sword in the Stone.

Director:

Federico Fellini, 8½*

Kon Ichikawa, Revenge of a Kabuki Actor

Robert Wise, The Haunting

Alfred Hitchcock, The Birds

Elia Kazan, America, America*

The Oscar went to Tony Richardson for Tom Jones; I can’t imagine I’ll ever think he deserved it over Fellini, or even Kazan, who earned his final nomination after a really impressive run starting with A Tree Grows in Brooklyn in 1945. The other nominees were Martin Ritt for Hud and Otto Preminger for The Cardinal.

Actor:

Kazuo Hasegawa, Revenge of a Kabuki Actor
